title.narrative: Access to Justice and Jobs in Jordan- Addressing Root Causes

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Increased awareness of rights and access to legal support for refugees and host communities. Outcome 2: Improved employability of Jordanians and Syrian Refugees. Outcome 3: Existing and new Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (M/SMEs) expanded to retain existing workforce and expand employment opportunities.
The Consortium will contribute to the Dutch policy on Security and Rule of Law (S&RL) of addressing the root causes of conflict, instability and irregular migration in Jordan.

humanitarian-scope.narrative: This project relates to the 3RP response plan.

description.narrative: This overarching indicator falls under the ARC results area Overarching: Stability and Conflict

title.narrative: Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report that they see a socio-economic future for themselves in the area where they currently live

description.narrative: This indicator is used to gain insight into how the ARC programmes have contributed to the socio-economic ‘stability’ of the area where beneficiaries live and can be triangulated with data generated through the related life stories indicator (OA.5) which will be collected by the end of the programme. By ‘stability’ we specifically mean ‘legitimate stability’, which indicates that stability is not a goal in itself. We aim towards the form of stability that arises from social cohesion between population groups, and from citizens’ acknowledgement of the legitimacy of existing structures and institutions, both formal and informal. From a socio-economic perspective, ‘stability’ includes having a secure source of income. Stability of this nature, giving people a sense of security in terms of their ability to maintain a sustainable livelihood in the long run, is a precondition for sustainable development.

comment.narrative: Q3: Will be reported through endline survey. This value is the same as the baseline value.- Q2: Will be reported through endline survey. This value is the same as the baseline value. - Q1: "Target has not been met because: The Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation (MOPIC) has not granted the Access to Justice and Jobs in Jordan programme permission to formally begin implementation within Jordan. Mercy Corps Jordan has been working actively towards obtaining final approval; over 10 coordination meetings have been done with the Ministry of Labor (MOL) and Ministry of Social Development (MSD). The meetings were held in order to re-name programme activities as well as make amendments to the programme budget in accordance to MOPIC standards. Right now Mercy Crops is waiting patiently for the MOL and MSD to write the agreed upon letter of endorsement in order to re-submit the application. It is to be noted that this does not affect the objective of the programme, activities proposed during the proposals and work plan, nor the budget. This delay in approval does not require any efforts from the Dutch Embassy in Jordan either. "

This quarter, the endline for the 4th cohort of mobile training was conducted. Out of 16 trained, 11 responded to the endline survey. Of those 11, 3 (27%) reported that they see a socio-economic future for themselves. So far the overall rate of change is 12% (17/138). In light of the current COVID-19 pandemic, IRC will report on this indicator once it finalizes its endline assessment, in the upcoming quarter.

"Q8: 2 Total Progress: 7% (8 out of 85) Youth: 8 Syrians: 8, Jordanian: 0 Males:8 " The endline has been conducted for the 1st batch of trainees who completed the mobile repair TVET 12 months ago, 13 out of 16 trained responded to the end line survey. 2 out 13 showed an economic optimism and are living within host communities.

title.narrative: J&SR have improved knowledge of labor and employment rights

description.narrative: "This indicator is measuring the increase of knowledge on Jordanian labor rights and law. Youth and women enrolled in IRC PYB/MYF courses will receive a session on labor rights. All programme beneficiaries participating in activities will receive an awareness session on Jordanian labour rights and law. All IRC employment training(s) and PYB/MYF will have a dedicated session on Jordanian labor rights law. "

title.narrative: % of improvement in knowledge for programme beneficiaries attending trainings/sessions.

description.narrative: "Age Category (Youth, Not Youth) Nationality Sex Sector of training Area"

target.value: Target: 60% of programme beneficiaries who have completed labor and employment rights training display an increase in knowledge.

comment.narrative: IRC measure the knowledge increased by asking main 12 questions divided as follows: - Access to finance - Methods to add value to the product and service - Market plan - Management of the accounting records - Soft and communication skills The highest knowledge increased was in management of the accounting records of the project. The Syrians showed a higher knowledge improvement than the Jordanian as the Jordanians recorded a higher scores in the pre test.
No new trained clients in Q8

The meetings were held in order to re-name programme activities as well as make amendments to the programme budget in accordance to MOPIC standards. It is to be noted that this does not affect the objective of the programme, activities proposed during the proposals and work plan, nor the budget. title.narrative: 4.1.1.5 No. of youth matched into a 3-month apprtenceship oppourtunity

description.narrative: Youth who completed transferable skill training, then matched into an apprtenceship in Irbid or Mafraq

comment.narrative: Q3: Implementation has not yet started

"MC awarded Al-Watin International Company a cost shared subgrant award. In quarter 5, grantee was able to match 42 Syrian and Jordanian youth into 3-month apprenticeships, the apprenticeships are within the hygienic sector and loading & unloading sector at took place at various hospitals and manufacturing businesses in Irbid and Mafraq. For the mobile repair sector, MC awarded Abu Jabal Technical Academy (TA) a cost shared subgrant award. Grantee used the funds to expand and update equipment in its existing training center enroll program beneficiaries into a vocational training course. At the end of the vocational training course 7 students (4 Irbid, 3 Mafraq) were selected and matched in 3-month apprenticeships. Their apprenticeships are being hosted at various mobile and tech-repair shops in Irbid and Mafraq. TA is currently completing an additional vocational training course and intends to match an additional number of youth with apprenticeships. "

title.narrative: 4.1.1.4 No. of youth enrolled in vocational training

comment.narrative: Q4: 16 youth have been enrolled in mobile maintenance vocational training with Abu-Jabal Technical Academy Q3: 101 youth completed vocational training within the construction sector

"

title.narrative: New and existing MSME’s in selected value chains are expanded to retain and/or create inclusive safe and dignified employment opportunities for vulnerable J&SR
RA 4.SG.2: # and % of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already) have grown over the last 6 months

description.narrative: Precise definition: Growth over 6 months indicates having continued and improved the economic benefits of an MSME. In the form of having the capacity to add a new business model, employed new individuals, secured their livelihoods. ‘Business’ is understood here as an organization or economic system for exchanging products and/or services with customers in order to make a profit in the formal or informal economy. A business may include the hiring of staff/personnel to work as contracted laborer. Rationale: This indicator measures basically how many trained/supported beneficiaries have been able to grow the benefits of their business activity. The indicator states therefore how many MSME owners who received training/support were able to grow their economic activities, assuming that there is at least in part a causal link between such support and their subsequent success. Disaageration: 1. Jordanian/ Syrian 2. Age 3. Female/ Male 4. MSME Type 5. Sector 6. Irbid/Mafraq 7. Programme events/networking events attended 8. What type of services did they receive to continue 9. Who provided the service 10. Formal/ Informal economy Unit of measure: Number and percentage of MSMEs who have received support and are able to grow their business activities over the last six months. Data source: MSME grant recipient Means of verification: 1. Follow up surveys with grant recipients 2. Financial records of MSMEs

comment.narrative: No baseline for this indicator
Q3: Will be reported through the endline survey

"Total Progress: 60% of 35 grantees (15 still in business while 25 have started in Feb 2018) Q6: 15, Youth: 2 & Non-youth: 13 Irbid: 12 Mafraq: 3 Jordanians: 3 Syrians: 12 " In Q8 IRC distributed grants for 46 clients at the one month follow-up, 21 of the 46 reported opening their business but this indicator for those clients will be reported in the last quarter, in order to identify businesses that started and measure their sustainability after six months.

title.narrative: Intermediate 4.2a: % of MSMEs demonstrate increasing inclusive recruitment /employment practices

description.narrative: Precise definition: Employment practices refers to a change of management practices at the organization level during the reporting year. Organization-level management practices include those in under human resources Rationale: This indicator is measuring the increase of MSMEs within the dairy and olive oil sector as well MSMEs in need for new hires who are hiring in a more inclusive matter. Disaageration: 1. MSME Type 2.Sector 3.Irbid/Mafraq 4.Programme events/networking events attended 5. Type of programme activities participated in Unit of measure Number and percentage of MSMEs who are have and are recruiting new hires in a more inclusive manner Data source: 1. MSME Grant recipients 2. MSMEs who are employing programme beneficiaries Means of verification: 1. Follow up surveys with beneficiaries who receive cost-sharing grants 2. Financial records when available

comment.narrative: Q3: Updated for Q3 - will be reported through the endline survey. Q2: Will be reported through endline survey. This value is the same as the baseline value.

description.narrative: Precise definition: Selected value chain refers to the dairy and olive oil VC Technical and management capacity Rationale: The indicator is measuring the technical and management capacities of the 30 MSMEs who have received cost-sharing grants in order to build their capacity. Disaageration: 1. MSME Type 2. Sector 3. Irbid/Mafraq 4. Programme events/networking events attended 5. Type of programme activities participated in Unit of measure: Number and percentage of MSMEs who have received support and are able to grow their business activities over the last six months. Data source: 1. Interview 2. Custom evaluation

title.narrative: MSMEs in selected VCs have improved access to market information, new markets, business service providers, and financial services
Short-term 4.2.2: Number of MSMEs in olive/olive oil and (dairy) VC accessing with the new products/services promoted by the programme

description.narrative: Precise definition: The number of MSMEs purchasing (in cash or on credit) or engaging with the products /services and/or rules. Access is defined as the availability and means to use and benefit from capacity building products, financial services, and new linkages Rationale: This indicator is measuring the increase of diversity happening across different actors within the each VC. Disaageration: 1. MSME Type 2. Sector 3. Irbid/Mafraq 4. Programme events/networking events attended 5. Type of programme activities participated in Unit of measure: Number and percentage of MSMEs who have received support and are able to grow their business activities over the last six months. Data source: 1. Event records 2. Follow-up monitoring from linkage events Means of verification: Event summary report

comment.narrative: No baseline for this indicator

actual.value: 61% or 43 SMEs; Irbid: 43; Olive oil VC: 43; Micro-business: 24; Small enterprise: 10

comment.narrative: Q4: No linkage events took place in Q4. As a program, 70 SMEs participated in B2B events and 43 indicated that their business increased its capacity and/or exposure due to programme interventions. Q3: 70 SMEs have participated in B2B events thus far, 43 of them felt that their businesses has increased its capacity and/or exposure due to programme activities. - Q2: Implementation has not yet started

title.narrative: Improved transferable skills, and attitudes of vulnerable J&SR towards vocational trainings and professions.
4.1.1b: % of individuals demonstrating increased knowledge in technical skills

description.narrative: Precise definition: Youth enrolled or participating in programme activities demonstrate uptake and retention of knowledge and skills after completion of training via pre/post-test, etc. Rationale: Youth make successful transitions to safe, equitable, and productive work. Disaageration: 1. Age 2. Female/Male 3. Jordanian/Syrian 4. Irbid/Mafraq 5. Type of training enrolled and completed Unit of measure: Percentage of beneficiaries who demonstrate an increase in knowledge in technical or transferable skills after participating in training. Data source: Youth enrolled or participating in programme activities Means of verification: 1. Attendance Sheets 2. Training evaluations 3. Pre/post test 4. This 80% increase will be determined by comparing the pre and post exam results (pre and post exams will be 10-15 questions)

title.narrative: O 4.2.1.17 Number of public and private sector training provider within the labor market who receive grants.

comment.narrative: New indicator starting from Q7 Access to Jobs and Justices project has partnered with 6 private and public institutes in Labor Market in order to implement the employability services provided to the target group. Additionally, the project has assissted most of the partners to expand into new areas, get CAQA accreditation and enhance their capacity

"Q8: 2 Total progress: 19 Irbid-Olive Oil: 19 " "One deal was made as result of promoting services of SMEs shared cost grantees during harvesting awareness session. The deal was between shared cost grantee Nursery “Tariq Al-Fadil” and land owner who attended harvesting awareness. The land owner bought 142 Roman Olives seedlings for 285 JoDs. 50% discount was provided to the land owner so the selling price per each seedling was 2 JoDs instead of 4 JoDs. In addition to that, Tariq al Fadil has conducted 3 awareness sessions on Roman Olive trees and promoted his services. One attendee bought 16 seedlings with 50% discount. "

title.narrative: RA4.SG.3 Improved employability and community engagement capacity of vulnerable J&SR
RA 4.SG.4 Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies

description.narrative: Precise definition: This indicator will be report on both the number of jobs created according to the MoF definition, as well as the Mercy Corps definition of employment/jobs. MoF: Jobs’: A Job working at least 5 days per week (or 240 days/year), with or without a contract, paid roughly at the market wage rate Full-time equivalent jobs created as a result of the programme. A full-time job is ongoing employment in which a person works a minimum number of hours defined as such by the Ministry of Labor or employer in Jordan. This employment could be with or without a contract. Full-time employment: Ongoing employment in which a person works a minimum number of hours as defined by the Ministry of Labor/local government or his/her employer. Full-time employment and number of hours worked varies by context. This employment could be with or without a contract. Seasonal employment: When the timing and duration of the labor contract is significantly influenced by seasonal factors such as the climatic cycle, public holidays and/or agricultural harvests. Seasonal employment can be part-time or full time. Part-time Job is ongoing employment where hours worked are less than full-time counterparts or less than normal for the context. Rationale: This indicator measures how many jobs have been created by companies for specific target groups that were supported through interventions of grantees, assuming that there is at least in part a causal link between such support and subsequent employment growth within Irbid and Mafraq. Entering the labor market, or finding that first job, is often the most difficult part of productive participation in an economy. While multiple income streams and short-term and seasonal work are often necessary (particularly in informal and/or agriculture-based economies), we believe that enabling individuals to find long-term, steady work is critical to ensuring that they play a continual, active role in the labor market. Disaageration: Type of service received Who provided the service Female/Male Jordanian/Syrian Youth/ Not Youth Irbid/Mafraq Vulnerability level Sector employed in Formal/ Informal employment Full-time equivalent/ Full-time employment/ seasonal employment Unit of measure: The total number of jobs created by companies supported by the intervention (cumulative). Data source: Youth and women enrolled or participating in programme activities Means of verification: Survey

comment.narrative: No baseline required for this indicator

dimension.name: "Target has not been met because: The Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation (MOPIC) has not granted the Access to Justice and Jobs in Jordan programme permission to formally begin implementation within Jordan. Mercy Corps Jordan has been working actively towards obtaining final approval; over 10 coordination meetings have been done with the Ministry of Labor (MOL) and Ministry of Social Development (MSD). The meetings were held in order to re-name programme activities as well as make amendments to the programme budget in accordance to MOPIC standards. Right now Mercy Crops is waiting patiently for the MOL and MSD to write the agreed upon letter of endorsement in order to re-submit the application. It is to be noted that this does not affect the objective of the programme, activities proposed during the proposals and work plan, nor the budget. This delay in approval does not require any efforts from the Dutch Embassy in Jordan either. "

This quarter, under Mercy Corps' partnership with Abu Jabal, 7 (4.8 FTE) jobs were created in the mobile repair sector. Over the past quarter, an internal data quality assessment was conducted, and the "Total Progress" has been updated to reflect accurate achievements to date.

"Non-youth: 6 Jordanians: 6 Males: 6 Agriculture- Pruning training: 6 Irbid: 6 " "Under the pruning campaign scheme which was facilitated by MC and implemented by the Directorate of Agriculture (DoA) in Irbid, pruners provided a discount to farmers who wish to prune their trees, in return Mercy Corps subsidized the discounted amount. As a result of the campaign, 6 freelance jobs as olive tree pruners were created. Based on Methodological notes: 1a) What type of services contributed to the creation of this job? Pruning subsidy in partnership with DoA of Irbid. 50% of pruner payment was paid by MC and the other 50% was paid by farm owner with DoA monitoring and facilitation. 1b) Who provided that service: Government / Private sector / NGO / Other? NGO (MC), Government (DoA), Private sector (smallholder farms) "

title.narrative: RA4.SG.3 Number and % of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed

description.narrative: Precise definition: "Type of services youth received: only TVET training (including soft skills on conflict reduction) / an apprenticeship / job matching / Other; or any of the various combinations of these Trained/supported programme beneficiaries’ refers to the youth coming whom have completed soft skills/employability training. ‘Employed’: having a paid job, working at least 5 days per week (or 240 days/year), with or without a contract, paid roughly at the market wage rate " Rationale: This indicator measures how many unemployed people who received training/support became employed, assuming that there is at least in part a causal link between such support and their subsequent employment. Disaggregation: "Type of service received Who provided the service Female/Male Jordanian/Syrian Youth/ Not Youth Irbid/Mafraq Vulnerability level Sector employed in Formal/ Informal employment" Unit of measure: Number and percentage of trained programme beneficiaries who are employed Source of data: Youth and women enrolled or participating in programme activities Means of verification: "On-going tracking Exit survey Semi-structured interviews with beneficiaries Data collected from private and public sector institutions "

title.narrative: Improved social and professional networks
4.1.2: % of people reporting inter-personal and professional connections that provide helpful resources.

description.narrative: Precise definition: This indicator is measuring the % of programme beneficiaries who have inter-personal and professional connections that have proved to be useful and have better positioned them in the labor market. Better positioning in the labor market refers to programme beneficiaries having more access to information, knowing where to go when looking for a job, and having the skills to network Rationale: There is a misconception around the idea of having strong business connections/networking circle and 'wasta' which is the notion of obtaining job just for knowing someone. This indicator will map the new connections programme beneficiaries are making and also measure if those connections are benefiting them. Disaageration: 1. Female/Male 2. Jordanian/Syrian 3. Youth/Not Youth 4. Irbid/Mafraq 5. Activities participated in 6. Events and networking events attended Unit of measure: Percentage of programme beneficiaries who made new connections due to programme interventions and found them useful Data source: Youth and women enrolled or participating in programme activities Means of verification: 1. Quantitative survey 2. Semi-structured interviews 3. Exit surveys from each networking event

title.narrative: SO 4.1.3a: % of improvement in knowledge for programme beneficiaries attending trainings/sessions.
Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the reoccurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration (emphasis on women and youth)
RA4.1.2 # and % of programme beneficiaries who report reduced personal grievance [e.g. those related to conflict, instability or irregular migration] regarding income / livelihoods (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise definition: Programme beneficiaries’ refers to the people to whom the intervention is directed. The exact definition depends on the local context and the rationale behind the indicator and is to be defined by the grantee(s). ‘Grievances [e.g. those related to conflict, instability or irregular migration] regarding income / livelihoods refer to complaints/criticisms/objections or a strong feeling from an individual programme beneficiary, that he/she has received an unfair (lack of) quantity or quality of income / livelihoods / economic perspective. Rationale: Result area 4.2 aims to reduce the grievances of people targeted by the intervention regarding income / livelihoods, in order to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration. This is done by increasing the ability of the target group to meet needs regarding income / livelihoods Disaageration: 1. Male/Female 2. Youth/Not Youth 3. Syrian/ Jordanian 4. Irbid/Mafraq Unit of measure: Percentage of beneficiaries who have been able to grow these activities over the last six months. Data source: 1. MSMEs who receive grants 2. Youth enrolled or participating in programme activities 3. Apprenticeship host businesses Means of verification: 1. Baseline/ Midline/ Baseline Surveys 2. Qualitative impact studies

This quarter, the endline for the 4th cohort of Mobile training was conducted. Out of 16 trained, 11 responded to the survey. Out of the 11 respondents, 2 (18%) reported reduced personal grievances.

title.narrative: RA4.1.1 # and % of programme beneficiaries who report ability to meet current and future (next 12 months) household needs (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise definition: "Full-time equivalent jobs created as a result of the programme. Additional jobs minus jobs lost. A full-time job is ongoing employment in which a person works a minimum number of hours defined as such by the Ministry of Labor or employer. The amount of net attributable income change (NAIC) indicates the value of the total amount of revenue accrued by individuals (e.g. poor farmers, entrepreneurs and employees) relative to a base year, and can be calculated based on the total amount of revenue minus any costs incurred during the reporting year minus the total amount of revenue minus any costs in the base year. ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refers to the people to whom the intervention is directed. The exact definition depends on local context and rationale behind the indicator and has to be defined by the grantee(s). ‘Household needs’: the minimum of resources necessary for the long-term physical well-being of one’s household, ‘Household needs’ relate to more than financial needs; it normally includes access to food A ‘household’ does not equal a family - what it means depends on each beneficiary’s personal responsibilities. Thus, a household could be: just one person living alone, a group of people who live together for socioeconomic reasons, a family, or a combination of two families living in different houses for a beneficiary who is (one of) the breadwinner(s) for those two families ‘Future needs’ refers to the expected needs of a beneficiary in 12 months’ time ‘ability to meet household needs’ refers to one being able to cover costs for all household needs. Also refers to the increase of one able to make decisions in regards to household needs. Scoring of Ability: ‘Ability’: is for this indicator defined as any of the following 4 levels (of having the minimum of resources necessary for the long-term physical well-being of one’s household) on a scale from 0 to 6 0: not at all able to meet household needs 2: partially able to meet household needs 4: almost able to meet household needs 6: able to meet household needs Rationale: "Result area 4.1 aims to reduce, through an increase in their ability to meet household needs, the grievances [defined in list of definitions] of people (targeted by one’s intervention) regarding income or livelihoods, in order to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration. This indicator measures how many programme beneficiaries indicate are able to meet current and future (next year) household needs as a consequence (long term outcome) of household members having participated in income generating and livelihoods opportunities directed at the prevention of the (re)occurrence of conflict, instability and/or irregular migration. This can be as a consequence of beneficiaries’ participation in e.g. training programmes directed at skills development to stimulate (self)employment / the growth of SME’s, or because their households and/or communities have participated in the development and implementation of livelihood development strategies. Disagreation: " Male/Female Youth/Not Youth Syrian/ Jordanian Irbid/Mafraq The 7 groups of beneficiaries with an average score of 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 ‘points " Unit of Measure: "Percentage of programme beneficiaries which have an average ‘score’ of 5 or 6 points when measuring the average of their level of ability to meet current and future (next 12 months) household needs on the above mentioned scale . Source of Data: MSMEs who receive grants Youth enrolled or participating in programme activities Apprenticeship host businesses Women participating in programme activities Means verification: "Baseline/ Midline/ End line Surveys Quantitative surveys throughout the programme"

description.narrative: "This indicator is measuring the number of program beneficaires working in the dairy and/or olive oil who obtained a job or became employed as a result of the program training. Jobs and employment are defined as follows: Employment can be formal and informal, including engagement in agriculture. Full-time employment: Ongoing employment in which a person works a minimum number of hours as defined by the Ministry of Labor/local government or his/her employer. Seasonal employment: When the timing and duration of the labor contract is significantly influenced by seasonal factors such as the climatic cycle, public holidays and/or agricultural harvests. Seasonal employment can be part-time or full time. "

Mercy Corps Jordan has been working actively towards obtaining final approval; over 10 coordination meetings have been done with the Ministry of Labor (MOL) and Ministry of Social Development (MSD). The meetings were held in order to re-name programme activities as well as make amendments to the programme budget in accordance to MOPIC standards. Right now Mercy Crops is waiting patiently for the MOL and MSD to write the agreed upon letter of endorsement in order to re-submit the application. It is to be noted that this does not affect the objective of the programme, activities proposed during the proposals and work plan, nor the budget. This delay in approval does not require any efforts from the Dutch Embassy in Jordan either."

title.narrative: No. of programme-supported beneficiaries who gain access to income-generating opportunities
No. of programme-supported beneficiaries who gain access to income-generating opportunities

comment.narrative: Q12: 10 Total Progress: 271 Beauty: 16 Construction: 72 Loading and Unloading and Hygenic: 10 Mobile: 42 Solar: 27 Olive: 84 Dairy: 20 This quarter, the endline for the 4th cohort of mobile training was conducted. In total, 10 (90%) beneficiaries gained access to income generating opportunities.
